en_second_half: develope. She was a woman of mean understanding, little information, and uncertain temper. When she was discontented, she fancied herself nervous. The business of her life was to get her daughters married: its solace was visiting and news.
en_results: develope, and she was generally more in danger of being too much dazzled by his brilliancy, than of being wearied by his whims. His being a widower, with five children, was a circumstance most favourable to his making a choice in marriage,
en_results_raw: develope, and she was generally more in danger of being too much dazzled by his brilliancy, than of being wearied by his whims. His being a widower, with five children, was a circumstance most favourable to his making a choice in marriage, and the society of the neighbourhood being small, it was but a short time before the usual and inevitable consequence of such a situation, took place. The gentlemen of the neighbourhood, and those of the neighbouring towns, were all anxious to make his acquaintance, and to shew him every possible attention, and the ladies, as is usual in such cases, were not backward in shewing their regard for him, and their desire to make his acquaintance. Mrs. Bennet, who had been a beauty in her youth, and was still a handsome woman, was particularly anxious to make his acquaintance, and to shew him every possible attention, and her daughters, who were all young, and handsome, and lively, were equally anxious to make his acquaintance, and to shew him every possible attention. The consequence of this was, that Mr. Bennet was soon surrounded by a crowd of admirers, and his house was constantly filled with company, and his table was always spread with the most delicious viands, and the most exquisite wines. But, notwithstanding all this, Mr. Bennet was not happy, for he was a man of great sensibility, and great pride, and he was not pleased with the attention that was shewn him, for he thought that it was not sincere, and that it was only shewn him, because he was a rich man, and a widower, and not because he was a man of merit, and a man of worth. He was, therefore, very reserved, and very haughty, and he did not shew much pleasure, in the company of those who surrounded him, and he did not seem to enjoy the viands, and the wines, that were set before him. This behaviour, of course, gave great offence to Mrs. Bennet, and to her daughters, and they did not know how to account for it, for they had never seen him behave in such a manner before, and they did not know what to make of it. They, therefore, endeavoured to make him more cheerful, and more pleasant, but all their endeavours, were in vain, for he continued to be reserved, and haughty, and he did not seem to enjoy their company, or their conversation. This, of course, made them very unhappy, and they did not know what to do, for they had never been used to be treated in such a manner, and they did not know how to behave. They, therefore, endeavoured to avoid him, as much as possible, and to shun his company, but this, of course, only made him more reserved, and more haughty, and he did not seem to enjoy their absence, or their silence. This, of course, made them very miserable, and they did not know what to do, for they had never been used to be treated in such a manner, and they did not know how to behave.

But the steadiness of his attachment, though it may have been less romantic, was more satisfactory, more to be depended on, than the fervent adoration of the other. Elizabeth was not in a humour to endure such nonsense, and therefore turned away, to hide a smile which she could not repress. Mr. Darcy, however, was not so easily deterred. He followed her into the breakfast room, and soon after, the other gentlemen joined them, and the conversation became general. Elizabeth, still in a lively humour, contributed largely to the amusement of the party, and Mr. Darcy, though he did not say much, listened with an air of interest, which was very flattering to her vanity. As the morning wore away, the weather, which had been threatening all the morning, began to clear up, and the sun broke out, just as they were setting out on their walk. The party consisted of the two families, and Mr. Bingley, who had been invited to join them. They set out in high spirits, and Elizabeth, as she walked along, could not help feeling a sense of pleasure and satisfaction, which she had not felt for many days. The fresh air, the beautiful scenery, and the lively company, all combined to raise her spirits, and she felt herself becoming more and more cheerful, as the day wore on. Mr. Darcy, who was walking by her side, seemed to be in a similar humour, and they chatted and laughed together, like old friends. Elizabeth could not help but notice the change in his manner, and she began to wonder, if he was not, after all, going to turn out to be a very agreeable acquaintance. As they walked along, they came to a beautiful spot, where the valley opened out, and the eye could see for miles around. They all stopped to admire the view, and Elizabeth, as she gazed out at the beautiful scene, felt a sense of peace and contentment, which she had not felt for many months. Mr. Darcy, who was standing by her side, seemed to be feeling the same, and they stood there, in silence, taking in the beauty of the scene, and enjoying the peacefulness of the moment. As they stood there, Elizabeth could not help but feel a sense of gratitude towards Mr. Darcy, for bringing her to this beautiful spot, and for being such a agreeable companion. She turned to him, and smiled, and he, catching her eye, smiled back, and they stood there, for a moment, enjoying each other's company, in comfortable silence.

I shall be glad to see you and Miss Bennet reconciled, and I shall do every thing in my power to promote that end. But I must insist that you shall not allow Mr. Darcy's behaviour to influence your actions, or to induce you to do any thing that you would not otherwise do. You must be guided by your own sense of what is right, and not by any consideration of what others may think or say.

She had not gone far when she heard a rustling in the bushes, and out came a little rabbit, who looked at her with his big, bright eyes, and asked her where she was going in such a hurry. The little girl explained her situation, and the rabbit listened attentively, nodding his head from time to time. When she had finished, he said, "I can help you, but you must first help me. I have lost my way, and I need someone to show me the way back to my burrow. If you do this for me, I will give you a special gift that will help you find your way home." The little girl agreed, and together they set off through the forest, the rabbit leading the way.

Sir William se levantó y se acercó a la chimenea, donde se quedó mirando el fuego con una expresión pensativa. La señora se quedó sentada, con los ojos fijos en su labor de costura, pero no parecía estar prestando mucha atención a ella. El silencio en la habitación era casi palpable, y parecía que el tiempo se había detenido. De repente, Sir William habló, rompiendo el silencio. "¿Te gustaría un vaso de vino, mi querida?" preguntó, volviéndose hacia ella. La señora levantó la vista y sonrió ligeramente. "Sí, por favor", respondió. Sir William se acercó a la mesa y se sirvió un vaso de vino para cada uno. Luego se sentó a su lado y le dio un vaso. "¿Qué te parece si hablamos de algo más alegre?" sugirió, sonriendo. La señora sonrió también y asintió con la cabeza. "Me gustaría", dijo. Y así, la conversación se reanudó, y la habitación se llenó de nuevo con el sonido de sus voces y sus risas.

Your mother will have told you that I have been making some inquiries about you, and I flatter myself that I have gathered from her that you are not entirely indifferent to my proposal. I am well aware that I am not a young man, and that my situation in life may not be exactly what a young woman of your beauty and accomplishments might have a right to expect; but I hope you will not let these considerations weigh too heavily against me. I remember, I was quite surprised at the time, for I had not expected to find him so very proud. I was told, that she was a relation of his, a cousin, or some such thing. I do not know, for I did not hear the particulars, but I am sure, that she was a relation of his, for she seemed to be on very intimate terms with him. I was quite surprised, to see him so very much at ease with her, for I had not expected to find him so very agreeable. en_results_raw: As it is, the house will neither be let nor occupied in a manner that can give that consequence to the village which a family of respectability in that situation ought to give. I do not know whether it is not a little inconsistent to be so solicitous about the neighbourhood, and yet to be so careless of the family that is to inhabit it. I am rather inclined to think that if Mr. Bingley were to marry a woman of a family entirely unknown to us, and of whom we could not secure a knowledge of their character, it would be a most unfortunate event for the neighbourhood; and I am persuaded that it would be much more to the advantage of the neighbourhood that he were to give up the place entirely, than that he should bring in among us a woman of whom we know nothing, and who may introduce a set of acquaintance that may be highly disagreeable to us.

But the remembrance of all this, though it could no longer be the cause of actual pain, was still so far from being indifferent to her, that the slightest mention of anything relative to it, would have been a most distasteful subject; and the mere idea of her sister's marrying a man, who, in his conduct to his first wife, had been only too like her unhappy father, was so inexpressibly painful to her, that she would have been quite unable to speak of it, without betraying her emotions. And now, to be obliged to speak of it to him, to him, of all people, who would be most triumphantly receiving the intelligence, was a mortification, she felt, beyond what she could have supposed possible. She was vexed beyond her patience, and almost beyond her self-command.

As they stepped inside, the warm glow of the fireplace and the soft hum of conversation enveloped them, immediately lifting the somber mood that had settled over them during their walk. Mrs. Bennet, noticing the return of her husband and daughter, excused herself from the group and made her way towards them, a look of eager curiosity on her face. "Well, my dears," she began, her voice low and conspiratorial, "I trust you have had a pleasant walk? The fresh air has done you good, I daresay. You both look much revived." Trong khi đó, ông Bennet đã bước vào phòng khách, bắt tay ông Bingley và nói: "Xin chào ông, tôi rất hân hạnh được gặp ông. Tôi hy vọng ông có một chuyến đi đường tốt lành." Ông Bingley mỉm cười và đáp lại: "Cảm ơn ông Bennet, tôi cũng rất hân hạnh được gặp ông. Tôi đã có một chuyến đi đường khá tốt, mặc dù thời tiết có hơi xấu." Các cô Bennet bước vào phòng, mặt đỏ bừng vì vội vã, nhưng vẫn cố gắng mỉm cười và chào đón ông Bingley. Ông Bennet giới thiệu các con gái của mình cho ông Bingley, và ông đã chào đón từng người một cách lịch sự.
